RULES:
Syllable Rules:
LAGHU vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

Verse Rules:
The verse contains 32 syllables/akshara and 4 padas in total.
The verse is divided in 2 lines, each containing 16 syllables.
Each line is divided into 2 padas (quartets),each containing exactly 8 syllables.
The fifth syllable of every pada must be LAGHU or short.
The sixth syllable of every pada must be GURU or long.
The seventh syllable of the second and the fourth pada must be HRASVA
The seventh syllable of the first and third paada must be DEERGHA

Shlok: नित्यं स्मरति रामस्त्वां ससुग्रीव स्सलक्ष्मणः।दिष्ट्या जीवसि वैदेहि राक्षसीवशमागता।।

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upajāti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upajāti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryāgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:
LAGHU vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

meaning: इसी प्रकार से बुद्धि का भेद सब में नहीं है जैसे दाता धीरज को प्राप्त होता है और उसका यश फैल जाता है इसी तरह परमात्मा का यश फैला हुआ है

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryāgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.

The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the udgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras
It is the inverse of the standard Āryā meter's structure.
The verse is divided into two lines: a first half (pūrvārdha) of 27 mātrās and a second half (uttarārdha) of 30 mātrās.
The first half contains two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The second half contains two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryāgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:
LAGHU vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

meaning: सदनन्तर पाण्डुके महारथी पुत्र सुधमको परासा करने के पश्चात् सब गौओंको लौटाकर और लूटका सारा धन वापस लेकर चले

Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the udgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras
It is the inverse of the standard Āryā meter's structure.
The verse is divided into two lines: a first half (pūrvārdha) of 27 mātrās and a second half (uttarārdha) of 30 mātrās.
The first half contains two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The second half contains two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryāgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the udgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras
It is the inverse of the standard Āryā meter's structure.
The verse is divided into two lines: a first half (pūrvārdha) of 27 mātrās and a second half (uttarārdha) of 30 mātrās.
The first half contains two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The second half contains two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryāgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:

HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ

Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras
It is the inverse of the standard Āryā meter's structure.
The verse is divided into two lines: a first half (pūrvārdha) of 27 mātrās and a second half (uttarārdha) of 30 mātrās.
The first half contains two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The second half contains two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryāgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:
LAGHU vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

meaning: कलियुगका अन्त आनेपर न तो कोई किसीसे कन्याकी बाचना करेगा और न कोई कन्यादान ही करेगा उस समयके वरकन्या स्वयं ही एक दूसरेको चुन लेंगे

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upagīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 27 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

is always marked guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upajāti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.
Syllable Rules:
LAGHU vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

meaning: दुर्धर्ष देव ! क्या मैं आपको आत्मदान करके भी सती साध्वी रह सकती हूँ ? आपमें ही देहधारियोंके धर्म, यश, कीर्ति तथा आयु प्रतिष्ठित हैं

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upajāti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.
Syllable Rules:
LAGHU vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

Verse Rules:
This is an Ardhasamavṛtta (half-uniform meter). Viyoginī is the most common example in this class.
The verse contains 42 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total.
The odd pādas (1st and 3rd) contain 10 syllables with the pattern: सगण (LLG), सगण (LLG), जगण (LGL), followed by a Guru (G). Pattern: LLG LLG LGL G.
The even pādas (2nd and 4th) contain 11 syllables with the pattern: सगण (LLG), भगण (GLL), रगण (GLG), followed by a Laghu (L) and a Guru (G). Pattern: LLG GLL GLG LG.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ

Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)

meaning: शुभे ! मुझे अपने लिये उतना शोक नहीं है, जितना कि पिताके लिये और उन्हींका अनुसरण करनेवाली दुबली पतली माताके लिये है  ॥

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upagīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 27 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upagīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 27 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

L means Laghu, G means Guru.

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upajāti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryāgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:
LAGHU vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryā meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), not based on a fixed syllable count per pāda.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two lines: a first half (pūrvārdha) of 30 mātrās and a second half (uttarārdha) of 27 mātrās.
The first half contains two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The second half contains two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
Constraint: In the first half, the sixth four-mātrā block must be a Jagaṇa (LGL). The odd-numbered four-mātrā blocks (1st, 3rd, 5th, 7th) must not be a Jagaṇa.

GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ

Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the udgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras
It is the inverse of the standard Āryā meter's structure.
The verse is divided into two lines: a first half (pūrvārdha) of 27 mātrās and a second half (uttarārdha) of 30 mātrās.
The first half contains two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The second half contains two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:

HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upagīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 27 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryāgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:

GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.

Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the udgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras
It is the inverse of the standard Āryā meter's structure.
The verse is divided into two lines: a first half (pūrvārdha) of 27 mātrās and a second half (uttarārdha) of 30 mātrās.
The first half contains two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The second half contains two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upagīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 27 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upagīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 27 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.

Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras
It is the inverse of the standard Āryā meter's structure.
The verse is divided into two lines: a first half (pūrvārdha) of 27 mātrās and a second half (uttarārdha) of 30 mātrās.
The first half contains two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The second half contains two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upajāti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.
Syllable Rules:

DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

meaning: हे मुरारे ! भोजन पकानेके समय आप मुरलीका मधुर रव न किया करें,क्योंकि उससे ये सूखी लकड़ियाँ सरस हो जाती हैं और अग्नि भी मन्दपड़ जाती है
prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upagīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 27 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 15 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.

Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryāgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:

HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ

meaning: विभो ! तत्पश्चात् असुराधम हिरण्याक्षद्वारा रसातलमें रखी हुई पृथ्वी को देखकर मायावराहवपुधारी आपने आक्रमण करनेवाले नीच राक्षसों की अवहेलना करके शीघ्र ही उस वमुधा को अपनी दाढ़ोंके अग्रभागपर लीलापूर्वक धारण कर लिया

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upajāti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.
Syllable Rules:
LAGHU vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:

GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.

Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

meaning: अर्जुन बोले श्रीकृष्ण ! पूर्वकालमें गन्धमादन पर्वतपर आपने यत्राह मुनिके रूपमें दस हजार वर्षोंतक विचरण किया है अर्थात् नारायणऋषिके रूपमें निवास किया है

A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the āryāgīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This meter is also known as Gīti. It is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter).
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:
LAGHU vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

meaning: अव्यक्तसे भी पुरुष श्रेष्ठ है और वह व्यापक तथा अलिङ्ग है; जिसे जानकर मनुष्य मुक्त होता है और अमरत्व को प्राप्त हो जाता है

prompt:
The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja
Syllable Rules:

GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upajāti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.
Syllable Rules:

GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ

DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the upajāti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mixed meter (an Ardhasamavṛtta), not a fixed-pattern verse.
The verse contains 44 syllables (akṣaras) and 4 pādas (lines) in total, with each pāda containing 11 syllables.
Each of the four pādas can independently be either Indravajrā or Upendravajrā.
The Indravajrā pattern is: तगण (GGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: GGL GGL LGL GG)
The Upendravajrā pattern is: जगण (LGL), तगण (GGL), जगण (LGL), followed by two Guru (GG) syllables. (Pattern: LGL GGL LGL GG)
A valid Upajāti verse can have any combination of these two patterns across its four pādas.
L means Laghu, G means Guru.

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the gīti meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
This is a mātrā-chandas (mora-timed meter), a variety of the Āryā meter.
Each gana can be any one of Nala (LLLL), GaGa (GG), Bha (GLL), Ja (LGL), Sa (LLG) each having 4 matras.
The verse is divided into two identical halves (pūrvārdha and uttarārdha), each containing 30 mātrās.
Each half is typically divided into two pādas of 12 and 18 mātrās respectively.
The rules of the standard Āryā meter concerning the placement of Jagaṇa (LGL) apply to both halves:
Jagaṇa (LGL) should not be placed in an odd gana, i.e, in the 1st and 3rd ganas of 1st and 3rd padas, and in the 2nd and 4th ganas of 2nd and 4th padas. 
3rd gana of 2nd and 4th padas should be either Nala or Ja

The goal is to generate Sanskrit verse that follows the anuṣṭubh meter rules for the given input translation. RULES: 
Verse Rules:
The verse contains 32 syllables/akshara and 4 padas in total.
The verse is divided in 2 lines, each containing 16 syllables.
Each line is divided into 2 padas (quartets),each containing exactly 8 syllables.
The fifth syllable of every pada must be LAGHU or short.
The sixth syllable of every pada must be GURU or long.
The seventh syllable of the second and the fourth pada must be HRASVA
The seventh syllable of the first and third paada must be DEERGHA
Syllable Rules:
LAGHU vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
GURU vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
HRASVA vowels: अ, इ, उ, ऋ, ऌ
DEERGHA vowels: आ, ई, ऊ, ॠ, ॡ, ए, ऐ, ओ, औ
Syllable is marked laghu, guru and hrasva, deergha based on the vowel it contains.
Syllable containing anusvāra("ं") or visarga("ः") is always marked as guru.
Syllable that is followed by a conjunct consonant (saṁyuktākṣara)
is always marked guru.

Shlok: वर्धन्ते पक्षिसंघाध तथा पशुगवेडकम् गवाश्वं च मृगाश्चैव सर्वे ते पिशिताशनाः
meaning: फिर तो पक्षियों के समूह बढ़ने लगे गाय, बैल, भेड़ बकरे आदि पशु घोड़े मृग तथा मांसाहारी जीव सभी बढ़ने लगे
